page.title: 16Landscape & Buildings
page.content: The landscape is undulating and a chequerboard of hedged fields, averaging l87m. to the west & falling to 6lm. along the meandering valley of the Gamber brook, flowing NE/SW. The land rises again to l07m. to the NE. The soils are predominantly clays from the Old Red Sandstone, plus lighter sands and valley alluvium - providing lst-class farmland and worked for mixed farming and fruit. Patches of mixed woodland have been retained but larger areas, such as Scudamore Wood have been gradually felled since the war. Many farms and houses are stone-built and 200-300 years old, some with fine stone barns. Some are l6th century (Llanwarne Court: Hills Farm: Manor House, Pencoyd: and Trebaron). Record of a dwelling on this last site occurs for 923 A.D.
